rdf:Description.adsbib:abstractText: We present the first >=3.5 (conservative) or >=5.8 (sum-of-lines significance) detection of two warm-hot intergalactic medium (WHIM) filaments at z>0, which we find along the line of sight to the blazar Mrk 421. These systems are detected through highly ionized resonant metal absorption in high-quality Chandra ACIS and HRC Low Energy Transmission Grating (LETG) spectra of Mrk 421, obtained following our two Target of Opportunity requests during two outburst phases (F<SUB>0.5-2keV</SUB>=40 and 60 mcrab; 1 crab=210<SUP>-8</SUP> ergs s<SUP>-1</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>). Columns of He-like oxygen and H-like nitrogen can be detected in the co-added LETG spectrum of Mrk 421 down to a sensitivity of N<SUB>OVII</SUB>>=810<SUP>14</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP> and N<SUB>NVII</SUB>>=10<SUP>15</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>, respectively, at a significance >=3 . The two intervening WHIM systems that we detect have O VII and N VII columns of N<SUB>OVII</SUB>=(1.0+/-0.3)10<SUP>15</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>, N<SUB>N VII</SUB>=(0.8+/-0.4)10<SUP>15</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP> and N<SUB>OVII</SUB>=(0.7+/-0.3)10<SUP>15</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>, N<SUB>NVII</SUB>=(1.4+/-0.5)10<SUP>15</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>, respectively. We identify the closest of these two systems with an intervening WHIM filament at cz=3300+/-300 km s<SUP>-1</SUP>. The second system, instead, at cz=8090+/-300 km s<SUP>-1</SUP>, is identified with an intervening WHIM filament located ~13 Mpc from the blazar. The filament at cz=3300+/-300 lies <~5 Mpc from a known H I Ly system at cz=3046+/-12 km s<SUP>-1</SUP> (Shull and coworkers) whose 3 maximal H I kinetic temperature, as derived from the observed line FWHM, is T<=1.210<SUP>5</SUP> K. This temperature is inconsistent with the temperature measured for the X-ray filament, so if the systems are related, a multiphase WHIM is required. Combining UV and far-ultraviolet (FUV) upper limits on the H I Ly and the O VI<SUB>2s-->2p</SUB> transitions with our measurements in the X-rays, we show that, for both filaments, equilibrium collisional ionization (with residual photoionization by both the diffuse UV and X-ray background and the beamed emission of Mrk 421 along our line of sight) provides acceptable solutions. These solutions define ranges of temperatures, metallicity ratios, and equivalent H column densities, which are in good agreement with the predictions of hydrodynamical simulations for the formation of large-scale structures in the universe. From the detected number of WHIM filaments along this line of sight we can estimate the number of O VII filaments per unit redshift with columns larger than 710<SUP>14</SUP> cm<SUP>-2</SUP>, dN<SUB>OVII</SUB>/dz(N<SUB>OVII</SUB>>=710<SUP>14</SUP>)=67<SUP>+88</SUP><SUB>-43</SUB>, consistent, within the large 1 errors, with the hydrodynamical simulation predictions of dN<SUB>OVII</SUB>/dz(N<SUB>OVII</SUB>>=710<SUP>14</SUP>)=30. Finally, we measure a cosmological mass density of X-ray WHIM filaments <SUB>b</SUB>=0.027<SUP>+0.038</SUP><SUB>-0.019</SUB>10<SUP>[O/H]<SUB>-1</SUB></SUP>, consistent with both model predictions and the estimated number of ``missing'' baryons at low redshift.
